results.headline: ‘Now & Later’ Explores Sex and Politics
results.summary_short: “Now & Later,” starring Shari Solanis, combines graphic sex and politics, though it’s hard to pay attention to one of the two (guess which).

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Now & Later

results.headline: Tooth-and-Claw Life of a Dedicated Single Mother
results.summary_short: “The Last Lions,” a heart-heavy wildlife documentary about the burdens of parenthood in a lion family, was created by Dereck and Beverly Joubert and narrated by Jeremy Irons.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Last Lions

results.headline: ‘Immigration Tango,’ International Love
results.summary_short: In “Immigration Tango,” an immigrant couple strikes a deal with an American couple: the woman from one will marry the man from the other, and vice versa.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Immigration Tango

results.headline: Tales of Teenage Aliens
results.summary_short: Directed by D. J. Caruso, “I Am Number Four” is a high school movie with a dollop of science fiction: teenage aliens are being pursued by evil Mogadorians.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Am Number Four

results.headline: ‘The Chaperone’: Wrestling With Laughs
results.summary_short: In “The Chaperone” the professional wrestler Triple H stars as a former thug, now gentle giant, who wants to be part of his daughter’s life.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Chaperone

results.headline: Bridges Can Still Exist in a Divided Land
results.summary_short: “Zero Bridge” is a moving slice of life from a corner of the world usually seen only in news reports.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Zero Bridge

results.headline: Stillness Amid A Shifting World
results.summary_short: “Port of Memory” by the Palestinian director Kamal Aljafari focuses on the stillness of its characters, who live in Jaffa, Israel.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Port of Memory

results.headline: Consider an Apple, Consider the World
results.summary_short: The South Korean director Lee Chang-dong’s devastating, humanistic film “Poetry” is about the importance of looking closely at the world.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Poetry

results.headline: The Link Between Female Sexuality and Corporate Profits
results.summary_short: “Orgasm Inc.” walks a careful line between lighthearted exposé and gimlet-eyed journalism.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Orgasm, Inc.

results.headline: Fraternal Rivalry and Failed Ambition
results.summary_short: The bond between two brothers becomes irretrievably twisted in “Lovers of Hate.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lovers of Hate

results.headline: An Innocent Abroad, at a Convention in Iowa
results.summary_short: In “Cedar Rapids,” an insurance salesman leaves his hometown for the first time to attend a convention, where he plunges into the reality of the world outside his tiny one.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cedar Rapids

results.headline: Return to a Spanish Village
results.summary_short: Mercedes Álvarez, in her film “The Sky Turns,” returns with a camera to the village of her birth in a rocky, empty region of northern Spain.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Sky Turns

results.headline: ’60s Snipper Extraordinaire
results.summary_short: “Vidal Sassoon: The Movie,” a biography of the famous hairdresser and his major invention: the geometric five-point haircut.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Vidal Sassoon The Movie

results.headline: An Oscar Film Festival, All in One Screening
results.summary_short: “The Oscar Nominated Short Films” provide a chance to see the shorts nominated for animation, live action and documentary.
results.display_title: The 2011 Academy Award Nominated Short Films

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The 2011 Academy Award Nominated Short Films

results.headline: That Hair! Those Eyes! His Fans!
results.summary_short: “Justin Bieber: Never Say Never” is billed as a concert documentary, but attention is also paid to that pop star’s legion of screaming fans as well as prefame home-movie snippets and segments with his handlers.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Justin Bieber: Never Say Never

results.headline: The Road to True Love Is Paved With a Whole Lot of Lying
results.summary_short: “Just Go With It,” a remake of the romantic comedy “Cactus Flower,” finds Adam Sandler and Jennifer Aniston in Hawaii.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Just Go With It

results.headline: A Kitsch-and-Tell Movie of Garden Variety Love
results.summary_short: When the humans are away, the lawn ornaments come out to feud or court in “Gnomeo and Juliet.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gnomeo & Juliet

results.headline: Back Then, a Man’s World of Loyalty and Adventure
results.summary_short: In “The Eagle,” a Roman military commander (Channing Tatum) in ancient Britain goes on a lonely and long-winded quest to retrieve the golden bird of the title.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Eagle

results.headline: Kicking Our Fossil Fuels Habit
results.summary_short: “Carbon Nation” sets out to show that weaning ourselves off oil and coal is possible.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Carbon Nation

results.headline: Crooked Lawyers and Broken People
results.summary_short: After informing us that traffic accidents are the leading cause of death for Argentines under 35, “Carancho” introduces the bottom feeders who profit from vehicular tragedy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Carancho
